title: Dow retains modest early gain but broader stock market knocked around by Ukraine-Russia developments
text:
Meanwhile, President Biden was set to suspend normal trade relations with Russia, as part of its sanctions to punish Putin for his unprovoked attack in Ukraine.

How are stock benchmarks trading?

The S&P 500 index SPX fell 2 points or 0.1% to 4,257.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA gained rose 105 points, or 0.3%, to 33,283.

The Nasdaq Composite Index COMP gained 60 points or 0.4% to 13,071.

On Thursday, the Dow industrials closed down 112.18 points, or 0.3%, to 33,174.07. The S&P 500 dropped 0.4% to 4,259.52, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.9% to 13,129.96.

What's driving markets?

Markets were wobbling early Friday, as investors remaining focused on headlines from Russia's ongoing invasion of Ukraine that began more than two weeks ago.

Stock index futures spiked overnight after President Vladimir Putin told his Belarusian counterpart, Alexander Lukashenko, that he had seen “certain positive shifts, negotiators on our side tell me,” of talks with Ukraine. In a meeting with Lukashenko, Putin said talks continued “practically on a daily basis,” according to a transcript provided by the Kremlin and reported by Russian news agency Interfax.

Major U.S. indexes were facing weekly losses of more than 1%, as investors have grappled with the continuing Russia-Ukraine war. The Dow is set to mark its fifth-straight weekly loss, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq are each headed for a third down week in a row.

However, Putin's comments came as Russian forces launched new strikes on airports in western cities on Friday, and Kyiv continued to brace for an onslaught. s Ukrainian authorities announced plans to both evacuate civilians and funnel humanitarian aid into the besieged city of Mariupol.

President Joe Biden is expected to announce Friday that the U.S. along with the EU and Group of Seven countries, will call for an end of normal trade relations for Russia over its invasion of Ukraine.

In U.S. economic reports, data from the University of Michigan consumer sentiment survey for March showed a fall to an initial March reading of 59.7 from February's level of 62.8, and expectations for inflation over the next year rose to 5.4% from February's expectation of 4.9%, marking the highest level since 1981, while inflation expectations over five years held steady at 3%.

The report comes after consumer price data released Thursday showed U.S. February consumer prices rose to 7.9%, a 40-year high, and some see that worsening due to the Russia-Ukraine war.

Goldman Sachs has cut its U.S. economic growth forecast, citing the effects of higher oil prices and the conflict on European soil. Oil prices were up about 2% on Friday.

The European Central Bank surprised markets on Thursday with plans to speed up the winding down of its asset-buying program, in response to rising inflationary pressures, and said the Russia-Ukraine war would negatively affect the region.

The Federal Reserve will hold its first policy meeting since the conflict began next week, with analysts widely expecting a rate increase of around 25 basis points.

What companies are in focus?

Shares of DocuSign Inc.DOCU tumbled around 20% after the online-signature company's annual guidance disappointed late Thursday.

Rivian Automotive Inc. shares RIVN fell 7.2% after the electric-truck maker said it lost more than $2 billion in the fourth quarter, amid continued supply-chain disruptions.

How are other assets trading?

The yield on the 10-year Treasury note BX:TMUBMUSD10Y fell less than a basis point to around 2%. Yields and debt prices move opposite each other.

The ICE U.S. Dollar Index DXY, a measure of the currency against a basket of six major rivals, rose to 0.2%.

Gold futures for April delivery GC00GCJ22 fell 1.2% to $1,977 an ounce.

Bitcoin BTCUSD fell around 1%, to about $39,000.

In European equities, the Stoxx Europe 600 XX:SXXP rose 1.3%, while London's FTSE 100 UKX gained 0.9%.

In Asia, the Shanghai Composite SHCOMP rose 0.4%, but the Hang Seng Index HSI fell 1.6% and Japan's Nikkei 225 NIK lost 2%.
